'''Charles Thomson''' (born 6 February 1953) is an English [[artist]], [[Painting|painter]], poet and [[photographer]]. In the early 1980s he was a member of [[The Medway Poets]]. In 1999 he named and co-founded the [[Stuckism|Stuckists]] art movement with [[Billy Childish]]. He has curated Stuckist shows, organised demonstrations against the [[Turner Prize]], run an art gallery, stood for parliament and reported [[Charles Saatchi]] to the [[Office of Fair Trading|OFT]]. He is frequently quoted in the media as an opponent of [[conceptual art]]. He was briefly married to artist [[Stella Vine]].
==Early life== Charles Thomson was born in [[Romford]], [[London Borough of Havering]], East London, England, and educated at [[Brentwood School (Brentwood, England)|Brentwood School]], [[Essex]], where he was class mates with [[Douglas Adams]]. While still at school he organised mixed media arts events and contributed to ''Broadsheet'', a magazine edited by [[Paul Neil Milne Johnstone]] and published by ''Artsphere'', a school arts group.<ref>''Broadsheet'', n.d., edited Paul Johnstone, Artsphere</ref> Outside school, he started the [[London Borough of Havering|Havering]] Arts Lab. this resulted in a headline "Sex Orgy Tale—Group Banned" in the local ''Havering Express'' newspaper. In 1971 he stood (unsuccessfully) as a Dwarf candidate in the Havering council elections, and was involved in anti-pollution protests. He distributed "[[Underground press|underground]]" magazines around London, including "Schoolkids [[Oz (magazine)|Oz]]". In 1975 he went to [[Kent Institute of Art & Design|Maidstone College of Art]], where he was the only person in ten years to fail the painting degree. 1979–87 he worked part-time as a telephonist and receptionist at Kent County Ophthalmic and Aural Hospital. 1987–99 he was a full-time poet, with work in over 100 anthologies.<ref name=Milner>Milner, Frank, ed., ''The Stuckists Punk Victorian'', p.106, [[National Museums Liverpool]], 2004, ISBN 1-902700-27-9</ref>
==The Medway Poets== {{main|The Medway Poets}} [[Image:MedwayPoets.jpg|thumb|left|[[Sexton Ming]], [[Tracey Emin]], Charles Thomson, [[Billy Childish]] and musician Russell Wilkinson at the Rochester Adult Education Centre 11 December 1987 to record [[The Medway Poets]] LP]] In 1979, Thomson was a founder member of [[The Medway Poets]], a punk performance group, who read in pubs, as well as the Kent Literature Festival and the 1981 international [[Cambridge Poetry Festival]]. There were, however, personality clashes in the group, particularly between [[Billy Childish]] and Thomson, who said, "There was friction between us, especially when he started heckling my poetry reading and I threatened to ban him from a forthcoming TV documentary." <ref>[http://www.3ammagazine.com/artarchives/2002_dec/interview_charles_thomson.html Interview with Charles Thomson on 3ammagazine.com]</ref> However, a TV South documentary on the group in 1982 brought them to a wider regional audience. According to Childish: "Me & Charles were at war from 1979 until 1999. He even threatened having bouncers on the doors of Medway poetâs readings to keep me out."<ref>[http://www.trakmarx.com/2004_02/10_billy.htm "Billy Childish on Stuckism", trakmarx.com] Accessed 9 April 2006</ref> Thomson has said this period was "an incredibly pressured and creative time and established the basis on which we are still working."<ref>[http://www.artistica.co.uk/2006/01/29/interview-with-charles-thomson-of-the-stuckists/ Interview with Charles Thomson on artistica.com]</ref> Other members included future Stuckist artists [[Bill Lewis]] and [[Sexton Ming]]. [[Tracey Emin]], then a local student, was on the out skirts of the group, being the girlfriend of [[Billy Childish]]. In 1987 Thomson printed her first book of writing, ''Turkish Tales'', which had been edited by Lewis and was published by Childish.<ref name=Milner8>Milner p.8</ref>
==Stuckism== {{main|Stuckism}} [[Image:Charles Thomson. A Long Way From Greece.jpg|thumb|''A Long Way from Greece'']] In 1999 Thomson was reconciled with Childish and together they founded the [[Stuckism|Stuckists]] art group with eleven other artists. Thomson coined the name "Stuckism" after an insult from [[Tracey Emin]] to ex-boyfriend Childish that he was "stuck", which Childish had recorded in a 1993 poem. The group stated its aims as promoting [[figurative painting]] and opposing conceptual art, being particularly critical of the [[Turner Prize]] and [[Charles Saatchi]]'s promotion of [[Young British Artists|Britart]]. Childish left the group in 2001 and Thomson remained as the figurehead, gaining extensive media coverage for his activities and outspoken views. In the meantime the Stuckists grew to a worldwide movement of over 100 groups in 30 countries.
2000-5 he staged yearly Stuckist demonstrations against the [[Turner Prize]] (making use of props such as clown costumes and blow-up sex dolls). He stood in the [[United Kingdom general election, 2001]], as a Stuckist candidate against the then-[[Secretary of State for Culture, Media and Sport|Culture Secretary]], [[Chris Smith, Baron Smith of Finsbury|Chris Smith]]. The same year he exhibited the then-unknown artist, [[Stella Vine]] (later made famous by [[Charles Saatchi]]). The couple married in New York and separated after two months.
[[Image:Stuckism International Gallery 2004.jpg|thumb|left|The [[Stuckism International Gallery]], Shoreditch, London.]] Thomson opened the Stuckism International Gallery in [[Shoreditch]] (2002â2005). In 2004 he reported Saatchi to the [[Office of Fair Trading|OFT]] (Office of Fair Trading) for alleged unfair trading practices in the art world: the complaint was not upheld. He co-curated the Stuckists' first major exhibition in a public gallery, [[The Stuckists Punk Victorian]] show at the [[Walker Art Gallery]], for the 2004 [[Liverpool Biennial]]. In 2005 he offered of a donation of 175 paintings by Stuckists artists from the Walker Gallery show to the [[Tate Gallery]]: this was rejected by the trustees. Later that year he obtained Tate Gallery minutes about the purchase of a trustee [[Chris Ofili]]'s work ''[[The Upper Room (paintings)|The Upper Room]]'' under the [[Freedom of Information Act 2000|Freedom of Information Act]]. This led to an ongoing press controversy about the purchase<ref>[http://www.stuckism.com/Tate/OfiliPress.html "Tate buys trustee Chris Ofili's work The Upper Room for Â£705,000: Press coverage"] stuckism.com. Retrieved 16 January 2009.</ref> and resulted into an official investigation by the [[Charity Commission]], who censured the Tate in July 2006 for acting outside its legal powers.<ref>Alberge, Dalya (2006)[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,2-2275993_1,00.html "Tate's Ofili purchase broke charity law"] ''The Times'' online, 19 July 2006. Accessed 19 July 2006</ref>
In June 2006 he wrote to the British Prime Minister [[Tony Blair]] asking him to intervene in the case of Stuckist artist [[Michael Dickinson (artist)|Michael Dickinson]], who was facing a possible 3 year jail sentence in Turkey for exhibiting a satirical collage of the Turkish Prime Minister [[Recep Tayyip ErdoÄan]].<ref name=blairasked>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,2087-2220955,00.html "Blair asked to help artist facing jail"] ''The Sunday Times'' online, 11 June 2006. Accessed 12 June 2006</ref><ref name=vatan>[http://www.vatanim.com.tr/root.vatan?exec=haberdetay&tarih=12.06.2006&Newsid=79736&Categoryid=7 "ErdoÄan'Ä± kÄ±zdÄ±ran kolaj iÃ§in Blair devreye girdi"] ''Vatan'' (in Turkish) online, 12 June 2006. Accessed 12 June 2006</ref>
In October 2006, Thomson exhibited paintings and presented an academic paper in both the [[Triumph of Stuckism]] exhibition and symposium respectively . Both these events were organised by [[Naive John]] for the 2006 Liverpool Biennial at the invitation of Professor Colin Fallows, Chair of Contextual Studies at [[Liverpool John Moores University|Liverpool School of Art and Design]].
He writes a regular arts column for [[3:AM Magazine]], which carries work by a number of Stuckists, ex-Stuckists and their opponents.
==Stella Vine==
{{See also|Charles Thomson, Stella Vine, and the Stuckists}}
[[File:Vote Stuckist 2001 Thomson and Vine.jpg|thumb|Left to right: [[Stephen Howarth]], friend, Charles Thomson and [[Stella Vine]] at the ''Vote Stuckist'' show in 2001, where Vine exhibited her work publicly for the first time.<ref name=sos23/>]]
In June 2000, Thomson gave a talk with Childish at the Salon des Arts in Kensington on Stuckism and Remodernism. It was attended by [[Stella Vine]],<ref name=salon/> who was following Childish after developing a "crush" on him.<ref name=waldemar>Januszczak, Waldemar. [http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/visual_arts/article1899443.ece "The Paint Stripper"], The Sunday Times, 10 June 2007. Retrieved 12 December 2008.</ref> She subsequently met Thomson<ref name=waldemar/> on 30 May 2001 at the private view of the ''Vote Stuckist'' show in Brixton, where she accepted his invitation to form The Westminster Stuckists group and to exhibit some of her paintings publicly for the first time in the show.<ref name=sos23>Thomson, Charles (August 2004), "A Stuckist on Stuckism: Stella Vine", from: Ed. Frank Milner (2004), ''The Stuckists Punk Victorian'', p. 23, [[National Museums Liverpool]], ISBN 1-902700-27-9. Essay text available on line at [http://www.stuckism.com/Walker/AStuckistOnStuckism.html#Vine stuckism.com.]</ref> On 4 June, she took part in a Stuckist [[Stuckist demonstrations#Trafalgar Square|demonstration in Trafalgar Square]] at the unveiling of [[Rachel Whiteread]]'s sculpture there.<ref name=salon>[http://www.stuckism.com/StellaVine/Salon.html "Stella Vine the Stuckist in photos"], [[Stuckism]]. Retrieved 18 December 2008.</ref><ref>[http://www.gettyimages.com/detail/1318399/Getty-Images-Entertainment?axd=DetailPaging.Search%7c1&axs=0%7c56344716%2c56270150%2c56270140%2c56270139%2c56270138%2c56270137%2c56270136%2c56270135%2c56270134%2c56270133%2c56270132%2c56270131%2c56270130%2c56270128%2c56270101%2c56270100%2c56270099%2c56270095%2c56270093%2c56270092%2c56270091%2c56270090%2c3120280%2c3120146%2c3120112%2c3120109%2c3107445%2c1318401%2c1318399 "New sculpture in London's Trafalgar Square"], [[Getty Images]], 4 June 2001. Retrieved 6 January 2008.</ref> On 10 July, she renamed her group The Unstuckists.<ref>[http://web.archive.org/web/20011015205854/http://www.stuckism.com/news.html#unstuck Stuckism news: Westminster Stuckists come unstuck"], stuckism.com, 10 July 2001. Retrieved from [[Internet Archive]], 9 January 2009.</ref> In October she had a painting in the first Stuckist show in Paris, curated by [[Elsa Dax]].<ref name=salon/>
Thomson and Vine had a two month relationship and they married on 8 August 2001 in New York.<ref>"Trouble and strife", ''[[Evening Standard]]'', p. 12, 20 August 2001.</ref> The next day, Vine said she wanted a divorce; they had an intense row, their room in the hotel was "trashed" and Vine told Thomson that she was refusing to have sex with him.<ref name=johnson/><ref name=deveney>Deveney, Catherine. [http://living.scotsman.com/ViewArticle.aspx?articleid=2511343 "Stripped bare"], Scotland on Sunday, 14 March 2004. Retrieved on 17 December 2008.</ref> She left him and they did not meet again till a week later at [[East India Club]] in [[St James's Square]], London.<ref name=strife>"Trouble and strife", ''[[Evening Standard]]'' (London), p. 12, 20 August 2001.</ref> They finally consummated their marriage.<ref name=waldemar/> He said that eventually he was unable to cope with her vacillations,<ref name=johnson/> and she said she could not cope with his controlling behaviour.<ref name=deveney/> The marriage ended in 2001 after about two months.<ref name=barber>Barber, Lynne. [http://www.guardian.co.uk/artanddesign/2007/jul/08/art "Vine Times"], 8 July 2007. Retrieved 16 January 2009.</ref><ref>[http://www.stuckism.com/thomson/indexStella.html "Charles Thomson: The Stella Vine paintings"], stuckism.com. Retrieved 23 January 2009.</ref> They were granted a divorce in October 2003.<ref name=billen>Billen, Andrew. [http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/article445303.ece?token=null&offset=0 "I Made More Money As A Stripper..."], 15 June 2004. Retrieved 9 December 2008.</ref>
In February 2004, after Vine "rose to fame after being championed by [[Charles Saatchi]]",<ref name=titans>Akbar, Arifa. [http://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/health-and-wellbeing/health-news/autism-charity-attracts-titans-of-the-art-world-395167.html "Autism charity attracts titans of the art world"], The Independent, 22 October 2007. Retrieved 18 December 2008.</ref> Thomson said that he was pleased that she had got success, but it was he and the Stuckists, not Saatchi, who had "discovered" Vine.<ref name=alleyne>Alleyne, Richard. [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1455188/First-blood-to-Saatchi-as-a-star-is-born.html "First blood to Saatchi as a star is born"], '[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', 24 February 2004. Retrieved 9 December 2008.</ref> Vine said that Stuckism was a misogynistic cult,<ref name=billen/> that she had quickly realised that the marriage and the Stuckist group were not right for her,<ref name=moneyissue>[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4159/is_20040307/ai_n12750971 "The Money Issue: answer the questions! Stella Vine - Princess Diana, Prozac and private views"], The Independent on Sunday, 7 March 2004. Retrieved 18 December 2008.</ref> and that her marriage to Thomson was "an utter disaster".<ref name=moneyissue/> During the relationship Thomson had paid off Vine's debts of Â£20,000,<ref name=deveney/> and Vine said she married him because this had been a condition of his funding her:<ref name=deveney/> "I couldn't face stripping any more and it was too bloody good to turn down."<ref name=deveney/> Thomson said that they had a business arrangement to promote themselves as an art couple, there was no condition of marriage, and that she was "really selling herself short" by saying that was her motivation.<ref name=denial>Johnston, Ian. "Former husband of artist Vine denies paying her to marry him", Scotland on Sunday, 21 March 2004. Retrieved 18 December 2008.</ref>
In March 2004, Vine said that she had only seen Thomson once, in an art shop, in the previous two years.<ref name=deveney/> She later told ''The Times'' that it was "impossible to explain"<ref name=malvern>Malvern, Jack. "Saatchi dragged into artists' dispute", ''[[The Times]]'' (print edition), 5 April 2004.</ref> why she married Thomson, that he didn't "give a s***<!-- NOTE TO EDITORS: ASTERISKS AS IN THE SOURCE--> about art or the Stuckist movement",<ref name=malvern/> and that he saw her as a means of gaining his own publicity: "When I met him and he saw some of my history, he saw dollar signs. He is a very exploitative man."<ref name=malvern/> Thomson said she showed herself in a manner to gain the largest amount of attention or sympathy, avoided reality and created a fantasy world : "Now it makes me question a lot of things she told me about her past."<ref name=johnson>Johnson, Angella. The Mail on Sunday (London), 7 March 2004, p. 38. Retrieved 18 December 2008.</ref> In June 2007, Vine said that the marriage was consummated in 2001, a few weeks after the ceremonyâ"I owed him that"<ref name=waldemar/>âand Thomson then paid off her debts of Â£20,000, after which "I've never seen him again."<ref name=waldemar>Januszczak, Waldemar. [http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/visual_arts/article1899443.ece "The Paint Stripper"], 10 June 2007. Retrieved 12 December 2008.</ref>
On 28 March 2004, Thomson reported Saatchi to the [[Office of Fair Trading]] (OFT) for alleged breaches of the Competition Act and cited as an example Saatchi's promotion of Vine, a situation which made the row "more bitter".<ref name=stummer>Stummer, Robin. [http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/this-britain/charles-saatchi-abuses-his-hold-on-british-art-market-567914.html "Charles Saatchi 'abuses his hold on British art market'"], ''[[The Independent on Sunday]]'', 28 March 2004. Retrieved 17 December 2008.</ref> The OFT said they did not "have reasonable grounds to suspect that Charles Saatchi is in a dominant position in any relevant market", which Thomson said was "just another cruel smack in the face" for Saatchi.<ref name=sos18>Thomson, Charles (August 2004), "A Stuckist on Stuckism: Charles Saatchi and the OFT attack", from: Ed. Frank Milner (2004), ''The Stuckists Punk Victorian'', p. 23, [[National Museums Liverpool]], ISBN 1-902700-27-9. Available online at [http://www.stuckism.com/Walker/AStuckistOnStuckism.html#OFT stuckism.com].</ref> In September 2004, Vine threatened suicide if her work was included in the [[The Stuckists Punk Victorian]] show at the [[Liverpool Biennial]], and the owner of the painting withdrew it.<ref>Pia, Simon. "Now the Stuckists are on the move", ''[[The Scotsman]]'', p. 22, 22 September 2004.</ref>
[[Image:Charles Thomson. Strip Club.jpg|thumb|''Strip Club'']] In October 2006, The Stuckists held a group show, ''[[Go West (exhibition)|Go West]]'', at [[Spectrum London]] gallery, including two of Thomson's paintings, ''Stripper'' and ''Strip Club'', "explicit images of his ex-wife."<ref>Barnes, Anthony. [http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4159/is_20060903/ai_n16710587 "Portrait of an ex-husband's revenge"] ''[[The Independent|The Independent on Sunday]]'', 3 September 2006. [http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-2043384.html "Portrait of an ex-husband's revenge: The vicious feud between artists Charles Thomson and his former wife, Stella Vine, has spilled over on to canvas."], The Independent, 3 September 2006. Retrieved 18 December 2008.</ref> but that she had painted images that were far more upsetting for people,<ref name=barnes/> that he would prefer her to enjoy them as he did her art<ref>Thomson, Charles. In July 2007, at the same time as the opening of Vine's major solo show at [[Modern Art Oxford]], Thomson, furious<ref name=moody/> at Vine's refusal to acknowledge her debt to the Stuckists,<ref name=moody>Moody, Paul. In September, Thomson wrote in ''[[David Lee (art critic)|The Jackdaw]]'', criticising the [[Tate]] gallery for not having work by a number of figurative painters, among whom he listed Vine,<ref>''[[David Lee (art critic)|The Jackdaw]]'', September/October. ==Sir Nicholas Serota Makes an Acquisitions Decision== [[Image:Charles Thomson. Sir Nicholas Serota Makes an Acquisitions Decision.jpg|thumb|''[[Sir Nicholas Serota Makes an Acquisitions Decision]]'', 2000.]] {{main|Sir Nicholas Serota Makes an Acquisitions Decision}}
His satirical painting of Sir Nicholas Serota, ''[[Sir Nicholas Serota Makes an Acquisitions Decision]]'', has been widely reproduced in the media and become a Stuckist icon. It has been reviewed: {{cquote|Thomson has painted what must be the masterpiece of Stuckism so far: ''Sir Nicholas Serota Makes an Acquisitions Decision''. Here the slick handling and smartass irony of [[Young British Artists|Britart]] are turned on its champion to make a very funny point and a rather good portrait. This is an example of what the [[Situationist International|Situationists]] called detournement, using your enemies' own weapons against him.<ref>Dean, Richard (2000)[http://www.superhumanism.com/html/imagespeak.htm "The Real Turner Prize Show 2000"] Imagespeak. Accessed from superhumanism.com, 17 April 2006</ref>}}
However, [[Sarah Kent]] (a staunch advocate of Britart) was less impressed with the satire: "One might forgive his puerile humour if Thomson didn't consider it a serious weapon ... cut the ranting and Thomson could be a reasonable painter."<ref>Kent, Sarah (2002) [http://www.stuckism.com/zPressText/5TimeOut5.8.02.html "The Stuckists: Stuckism International] ''Time Out'', 7 August 2002. Retrieved from stuckism.com, 18 April 2006</ref>
Thomson pointed out in response, "it's reality. A few weeks after I did the painting, Tracey Emin was shown on TV getting very angry about an installation because someone had substituted another pair of knickers for hers ... That makes it a bit sad."<ref>[http://www.stuckism.com/presscuttings.html#SarahKent "Sarah Kent of Time Out Rants"] stuckism.com 7 August 2002. Retrieved 18 April 2006</ref>
In October 2006, Thomson's painting of Serota was exhibited during the Stuckists' ''[[Go West (exhibition)|Go West]]'' show at [[Spectrum London]] gallery in London. It was suggested that this could be seen as revenge for the Tate's rejection of a Stuckist donation of 175 paintings the previous year.<ref>Teodorczuk, Tom (2006) [http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/arts/article-23364213-details/Modern+art+is+pants/article.do "Modern art is pants"] ''Evening Standard'', 22 August 2006. Retrieved 9 October 2006.</ref>
== Art technique == [[Image:Charles Thomson. I Feel Bad When I Reject Your Love.jpg|thumb|''I Feel Bad When I Reject Your Love'']] Thomson typically paints figuratively with black outlines and areas of flat colour, often brightly coloured. The painting, ''I Feel Bad When I Reject Your Love'' is not typical in this respect. He said: :Based on something a (now ex) girlfriend said to me. I thought it was a negative picture, but then I realised it was positive because itâs a reconciliation after self-knowledge. Itâs also ambiguous as to whoâs speaking. Most of my paintings are based on experiences with people I know, usually on a drawing from life, but in this case from a photo I took of her.<ref name=Milner/>
The paintings are based on spontaneous line drawings with a black wax crayon in a sketchbook. These are enlarged on the canvas. The colour is usually the first one on the canvas, though mixing it can take up to an hour. He likens colour to feeling and concludes, "The final image is a synthesis of material, emotional and spiritual experience."<ref name=Milner/>
